Comment: Hello to all of us, this is an interesting gambit benko game i played in a d4 thematic tournament.

c5 may start Benko defense
if white abandon the center with dxc, an easy why to retrieve it is Qa5+ and Qxc5. 
but of course it is not a good idea. 
90% white player may push d4-d5

black can now play 3.. b5 (benko) or (e6 benoni)
the Benko line
note that Qa4+ retrieves the lost pawn

fool black giving a second pawn...
note that benko gambit is one of most popular defense, and one of Polgar sisters preferred one.

the aim of benko black defense is to make pressure on a2 and b2 pawns
this activity is helped with a and b opened columns

main line.
gaining time to develop at queen side and now if white plays e4, of course Bxf1 Kxf1 and white king will have to build "manually" his castle with g3 Kg2
consolidating the center and preparing e4
the white reaction against benko gambit must be to take position at center.
the white reaction against benko gambit must be to take position at center.

the king's bishop fianchetto will add a force on b2. like the sicilian dragon, this bishop is very strong.
note that the black pawn structure is stronger than the sicilian dragon, with the c5 extended "dragon tail".

keeping the control on e5. white cannot push e4-e5 yet
another force on e5 !

defending e5 again and ... makes pressure on b2.

putting another force on e5.
but white did not solve their c1 bishop problem
generally, it is better to solve problems first, before attacking
black put another force on e5, and retreat the knight without loosing time.
white is over-protecting b2, perhaps to make their bishop going to d2 or e3 ?
transfer black forces at queen side, but making one less on e5
white attacks immediatly; a good reaction
